fields.description:
Modern browsers use an alternative 'print' CSS stylesheet to render a page prior to printing.  This CSS can eliminate parts of the page that are irrelevant in print, such as the header and footer.

JIRA should define such a print CSS (currently there is just one web-oriented CSS) and use it to eliminate the header, footer, menus, workflow steps and actions.
fields.summary: Remove header, footer etc when printing

fields.description: The printable view of an issue should not include the workflow options (Resolve Issue, Close Issue etc) or the actions (assign, edit etc).
fields.summary: Printable view of issue should exclude workflow options and actions

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-4578].
  {panel}

SITUATION:
I create project categories from different perspectives, i.e. 
1. a framework development and customer projects using its libraries.
2. development projects vs. QA projects vs. customer service projects.
3. a framework development and an QA project for this.

My JIRA project fits in multiple categories, i.e. it is a framework AND it is a development project.

Depeding on my role, I'm occupied with all service projects or with a project's development and QA, and so on.

PROPOSAL:
Allow to associate a project with more than only one category. Then I can configure my dashboard by selecting the category best fitting my point of view.
fields.summary: Assign more than one category to a project
Customization of initial workflow step

fields.description:
Add a changelog item for the workflowId when an issue is moved to a new workflow.

This will give a more complete history of the move issue operation.
fields.summary: Add a changelog item for the workflowId when an issue is moved to a new workflow.

fields.description:
Currently, attachment names in the change history issue tab panel are not linked. It would be very useful if they were linked so that you could download the attachment directly from there.

The main reason this is useful is that when you're using the "ALL" tab (to see all relevant issue details) you have to scroll all the way up to download the attachment, once you know when it was added!
fields.summary: Link attachment names in change history

fields.description:
Add a changelog history for issues migrated between workflows.

The OS_CURRENTSTEP entry for the original workflow entry should be moved to the OS_HISTORYSTEP table so as it can be referenced.
fields.summary: Add a changelog history for issues migrated between workflows.

fields.summary: Can't set the status of an issue when importing issues via jelly scripts.

fields.description:
When JIRA starts up it appears to query all the issues.  Unfortunately this involves n+1 queries.  This is problematic when we have many thousands of issues in the db.  A restart takes over 15 minutes.  Instead an optimized select should be used to query the entire rowset and parse each row. This would reduce much of the wasted overhead caused by the useless transaction demarcation that wraps each select.

ReIndexing would also benefit from this optimization.  I can manually perform all the select statements that retrieves all the data from the db in under 1 minute yet a reindex takes half an hour because of its inefficiencies.
fields.summary: JIRA startup causes very inefficient rebuilds of its statistics data structures

fields.description:
We have deployed JIRA to our devel and test environments as per usual application deployment here. Production deployment went fine after test acceptance was gained. We had also accepted the import / export procedure going between devel and test.

Going from test to production included subtantially more data to be migrated - developers liked JIRA so much they started using it before production. The test backup / export xml file is about 110Kbytes uncompressed. Attempts to import / restore this file to production results in the following error being displayed onscreen:

# Form Errors:  Exception occurred: java.lang.reflect.UndeclaredThrowableException

A largish stack trace can be found in the catalina.out file (not the atlassian-jira logfile, as defined in the context). Is starts like this, and continues for about 3,000 lines (probably more than one import attempt in these 3000 lines I have).

Can supply 3000 line stack trace + import file upon request.

fields.description:
Currently we can specify a description for each field of a field layout.  This description can be 255 characters.

Currently the description for custom fields can be 4000 characters.

This can cause problems when we pre-populate the field layout descriptions.

This probably has something to do with the user name case sensitivity. The specified user in the database has all lower case characters.
fields.summary: Unable to delete a project

fields.description:
When adding a new Workflow to a project the Issues are migrated from one step to another. If any Issue/Workflow Entry does not have a current step then an Index out of bounds exception occurs.

We need to fix these Issues either in an Integrity Checker or when migrating.

Also possible causes listed in comments:
 * We got it by closing these two issues while they were In Progress.
 * you may be suffering from connection closures which leads to issues having no current step
fields.summary: Migrating Issues to a new Workflow fails if a Workflow Entry does not have any Steps

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-4538].
  {panel}

Note: This issue has been discussed on the jira-user list in http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=6072&tstart=0

Some reports should allow configuration of the report inside the report page itself. This would allow the user to modify the report params without having to constantly switch back and forth between pages.

Example 1:

+---
| #Config section
| Report for group [Atlassian Developers|V]
| [X] Show Workload of individual product versions
+----
| # Report Data (remaining workload in days per developer per version)
|            |             | Mike        | Scott | ...
| -----------+-------------+-------------+-------+--------
| Jira       | Version 3.0 | 14          | 5
|            | Version 3.1 | 6           | 23
+------------+-------------+------ ...
| Confluence | Version 1.2 | 26

Example 2 (Version splitting turned off):

+---
| #Config section
| Report for group [Atlassian Developers|V]
| [ ] Show Workload of individual product versions
+----
| # Report Data (remaining workload in days per developer)
|            | Mike        | Scott | ...
| -----------+-------------+-------+-------+--------
| Jira       | 20          | 28
+------------+-------------+------ ...
| Confluence | 26


It is today possible to implement this (see forum thread mentioned above), but it's clumsy, involves duplicating original Jira code, and each plugin developer has do do this for each plugin.

A declarative solution would be much easier for the plugin developer, e.g.:

<resource type="velocity" name="view"
    location="templates/plugins/jira/reports/time-tracking-report.vm">

    <!-- default would be false -->
    <property name="allowInlineConfiguration" value="true"/>
</resource>

Jira would do all the plumbing for the plugin developer (include fields, generate form submission code, etc.).

A further improvement suggested by Owen: Might be worth allowing each property to be inlineConfigurable so you can just have some filter that are refined.
fields.summary: Allow inline configuration of reports

fields.description:
Currently we do not prompt for sub-task changes when we move an issue between projects.  We just set sub-tasks defaults automatically.

However, if we are moving sub-tasks to a new field layout scheme, where the field is required, and there is no default, then there will end up the case where the data is not set correctly.

There are many possible fixes for this (error messages, allowing sub-tasks fields to be set during move), but as we have to check the value of each field in the scheme, the most sensible way to do this would be to create a 'field' object which encapsulates this information (similar to a custom field).

As this requires a fair amount of work, I am putting this off to a later day, when all the benefits of having internal field objects are available.
fields.summary: Move issue may encounter problems if target sub-task scheme has required fields

fields.description:
Tomcat 5.5 has different handling for JNDI resources. <ResourceParams> have been folded into <Resource> tags. So instead of providing a bunch of <parameter> <name/> <value/> </parameter> tags, you now specify them inline as attribute of the <Resource> tag. Please update the documentation to reflect this; the current "Jira under Tomcat 5.0" documentation will not work.

Also, org.apache.commons.dbcp.BasicDataSourceFactory has been renamed to org.apache.tomcat.dbcp.dbcp.BasicDataSourceFactory so you should change this in all your configuration files.

User problem: 

"Often a random person will read a Mira issue that I logged and ask questions via comments.  If I know that that person is watching the issue, then I only need to update the issue with my comments.  If I don't know, then I will also need to forward the comment via email to that person".

Possible solutions:

* make the list of the watchers viewable;
* add oneself to the list of watchers whenever one comments on an issue
* "copy author and all commenters" checkbox when commenting

fields.description:

fields.description:
You should make absolutely shure, that all text strings have been moved to properties (including e-mails) when releasing version 3.0.

I've just translated the newest language file into danish and still finds a number of strings that are not translated. I hope it's becaus the file isn't completely compatible with 3.0.

This is a major issue for international customers and the people that on a volunteer basis spends time translating are wasting time when the property set isn't complete. Everytime a translator submits a bug all the others need to spend time translating once again.

Forthermore, when releasing new versions you should supply a changelog for the properties files so that is is clear what have been modified (added, removed) in the files since the latest version.

{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 23 April 2015|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#ebf2f9 | titleBGColor=#ebf2f9 | bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for voting and commenting on this issue. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with JIRA.

This suggestion is a priority for the JIRA development team, but I am not able to provide an accurate estimate for when this will be resolved. We will update this issue as soon as we can confidently project a release.

Please remember that jira.atlassian.com is one of many inputs for the JIRA roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

I understand that our decision may be disappointing. Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions.

Regards,
Dave Meyer
[dmeyer@atlassian.com|mailto:dmeyer@atlassian.com]
Product Manager, JIRA Platform
{panel}

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-4502].
  {panel}

The 'Comment viewable by' option displays all groups the user is a member, seems logical. But when the issue itself has been restricted by a security level the choices might not be logical.
For instance: a security level 'restricted' has been defined containing usergroups 'groupA',  'groupB' and 'groupC'
A user from groupA is also member of groups 'groupD' and 'groupE'.
When an issue has the level 'restricted' this user can add a comment and set the 'Viewable by' for 'All users', 'groupA', 'groupD' and 'groupE'.
It seems to me that 'All users' would translate to 'groupA' and the choices for 'groupD' and 'groupE' would not be usefull because members of those groups have no access to this particular issue.
So this option should not be available in this case.

Is the user also member of groupB it seems logical the 'Viewable by'  
would display 'All users' (being groupA and groupB), groupA and groupB
So the comment can be restricted to a particular group within the security level.

Does this make any sense?
fields.summary: Comment Viewable By not (always) logical when Security level is used

fields.summary: dashboard page is blank

fields.description: When browsing a project: In the information bar on the right, I'd like to see the "resolved" and "closed" count as in 2.6. As we use the last step, from "resolved" to "closed", as QA, I want to know how much QA is lagging behind development; the closer a version, the lower the "resolved" count must be in order to reduce uncertainty how much work is still ahead of us. Having this number at one glance has been very useful so far.
fields.summary: Project summary: want "Resolved" and "Closed" back

fields.description:
Checking out the 3.0 preview. While it is extremely useful to be able to create sub-tasks, we need the ability to re-group issues later on. Some use cases:

- It happens all the time that someone creates an issue which is later on found to be part of a larger one. No one knows every issue and finds a suitable parent right away.
- Or we decide to restructure issues later on.
- Or we migrate from 2.6, where we have defined a link type "Sub-Issue", as probably 90% of all Jira installations have; at least we want to manually convert this link type to the sub-task concept (as Lars Kühne posted on jira-users).
fields.summary: make an issue a sub-task

fields.description:
If I create a new version (say "1.0") and then create a new issue and set that issue's "fix version" field to 1.0 then the global road map displays a green bar with the text "1 of 1 issues have been resolved", even though the issue is not resolved or closed. Furthermore, underneath the version number where it lists the issues in the version, it displays the issue and says "UNRESOLVED" next to it.

The personal roadmap, however, displays a red bar and the text "0 of 1 issues have been resolved", which is presumably the correct behaviour.

Closing the issue and reopening it seems to sort this behaviour out, though in one case I've ended up with a version with a global roadmap that says "-1 of 1 issues have been resolved".
fields.summary: Global road map displays incorrect  bar graph and issue total for new version

fields.description: On the Edit page, I can enter '7-Sep-04' and submit without error.  This would trigger a 'date too early' error in lucene (because 04 expands to 0004), and the issue won't turn up.  We need to fix up the error handling here.
fields.summary: Insufficient range checking on date fields

fields.description:
JIRA does not impose an upper limit on date fields.  As a result, an invalid date can be entered that breaks lucene:

2004-09-04 11:46:30,969 WARN [jira.issue.index.DefaultIndexManager] There was an exception whilst reindexing issue
OPS-177java.lang.RuntimeException: time too late
java.lang.RuntimeException: time too late
        at org.apache.lucene.document.DateField.timeToString(DateField.java:106)
        at org.apache.lucene.document.DateField.dateToString(DateField.java:92)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.AbstractDocument.indexDateField(AbstractDocument.java:96)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.IssueDocument.getDocument(IssueDocument.java:64)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.DefaultIndexManager.indexIssueAndComments(DefaultIndexManager.java:183)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.DefaultIndexManager.reIndexIssues(DefaultIndexManager.java:109)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.DefaultIndexManager.reIndexAll(DefaultIndexManager.java:71)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.admin.IndexAdminImpl.doReindex(IndexAdminImpl.java:208)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.admin.IndexAdminImpl.doActivate(IndexAdminImpl.java:159)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.admin.IndexAdminImpl.doReindex(IndexAdminImpl.java:202)


We can fix this by imposing the date length limit that Lucene imposes:

  // make date strings long enough to last a millenium
  private static int DATE_LEN = Long.toString(1000L*365*24*60*60*1000, Character.MAX_RADIX).length();
....
    if (s.length() > DATE_LEN)
      throw new RuntimeException("time too late");
fields.summary: "time too late" errors while reindexing

fields.description: The RSS standard provides a mean for including large/binary files in the RSS feed under the term "enclosures", more information on this can be read at http://backend.userland.com/enclosuresAggregators - it would be great to have access to attached files as enclosures so that aggregation tools have the ability to reach these attachments.
fields.summary: Provide attachments as RSS enclosures

fields.description: While adding a new version, the release date picker returns the date in d-MMM-yyyy format e.g. 17-Sep-2004. If we try to submit we get a validation error complaining that the date must on the correct format d-MMM-yyyy. If we change it to the Greek month abbreviation the update is accepted. I suppose the date picker should be internationalized, to avoid correcting by hand.
fields.summary: Date validation issue while adding a version
